title: U.S. Government Partners with Citi to Commit $40M to Morocco's Attijariwafa Bank
summary: Citi Maghreb announced today that the U.S. Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) has provided its consent for a new $40 million, eight-year term loan facility with Attijariwafa Bank to support loans to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Morocco under a risk sharing agreement between OPIC and Citi.
tag-1: U.S. Government Partners with Citi to Commit $40M to Morocco's Attijariwafa Bank
tag-2: Citi Maghreb announced today that the U.S. Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) has provided its consent for a new $40 million, eight-year term loan facility with Attijariwafa Bank to support loans to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Morocco under a risk sharing agreement between OPIC and Citi.
tag-3: Matthew Lussenhop, Charge d'Affaires from the U.S. Embassy, Mohamed El Kettani, Chairman of Attijariwafa Bank, Boubaker Jai, Co-CEO, and Walter Siouffi, General Manager for Citibank Maghreb, attended a signing ceremony in Casablanca on July 31.
tag-4: OPIC, the U.S. Government's development finance institution, mobilizes private capital to invest in sustainable economic development and has supported multiple loan facilities to encourage lending to small businesses in developing countries. These businesses often struggle to obtain traditional bank financing.
tag-5: OPIC has a long history of supporting projects in Morocco and has provided finance or insurance support to 22 deals over the past four decades. The landmark agreement with Citi Maghreb marks OPIC's first risk-sharing agreement for the banking sector in Morocco.
tag-6: "OPIC is pleased to provide lending support to small businesses, which are, in aggregate, major employers and are central to every country's economy," said OPIC President and CEO Elizabeth Littlefield. "By supporting lending to the small and medium enterprises in Morocco, this deal will help these businesses to compete and grow their operations and contribute to the country's financial health and the wellbeing of its citizens."
tag-7: Mohamed El Kettani, Chairman of Attijariwafa Bank, said: "We are pleased with this agreement for a number of reasons:
tag-8: "Firstly, I would like to highlight that the Free Trade Agreement between Morocco and the United States of America is working and the agreement that we have signed today has deepened and strengthened our relationship and opened up new perspectives for Moroccan SMEs.
tag-9: "Secondly, this agreement highlights the long standing relationship between Attijariwafa Group and Citibank which have worked together for decades at building a strong partnership to serve the economies of Morocco and the USA. I would like to stress the fact that we are the first bank in Morocco benefiting from an OPIC guarantee.
tag-10: "Thirdly, this new financing mechanism comes at the right time to address the needs of the Moroccan economy and in particular the SMEs that are at the heart of our preoccupations and it complements other dedicated programs we are offering them.
tag-11: "Finally I would like to highlight our commitment to strengthen the relationship with American institutions and that our actions will further develop in the months and years to come."
tag-12: Walter Siouffi, General Manager for Citibank Maghreb, said, "We are delighted to be extending this medium-term loan to Attijariwafa Bank to support Moroccan SMEs, which are the backbone of the economy. This facility confirms our long term commitment to Morocco and our confidence in the prospects for the country."
tag-13: Citi Citi, the leading global bank, has approximately 200 million customer accounts and does business in more than 160 countries and jurisdictions. Citi provides consumers, corporations, governments and institutions with a broad range of financial products and services, including consumer banking and credit, corporate and investment banking, securities brokerage, transaction services, and wealth management.

tag-15: Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC)  OPIC is the U.S. Government's development finance institution. It mobilizes private capital to help solve critical development challenges and in doing so, advances U.S. foreign policy. Because OPIC works with the U.S. private sector, it helps U.S. businesses gain footholds in emerging markets catalyzing revenues, jobs and growth opportunities both at home and abroad. OPIC achieves its mission by providing investors with financing, guarantees, political risk insurance, and support for private equity investment funds.
tag-16: Established as an agency of the U.S. Government in 1971, OPIC operates on a self-sustaining basis at no net cost to American taxpayers. OPIC services are available for new and expanding business enterprises in more than 150 countries worldwide. To date, OPIC has supported more than $200 billion of investment in over 4,000 projects, generated an estimated $75 billion in U.S. exports and supported more than 277,000 American jobs.
